entry.title: Olga von Türk-Rohn (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that soprano Olga von Türk-Rohn (pictured) was celebrated for her interpretations of Franz Schubert's lieder?

entry.title: Gusuku period (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Gusuku period saw massive castles built on "virtually every ridge"?

entry.title: histamine N-methyltransferase (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the enzyme histamine N-methyltransferase regulates essential brain functions and sleep–wake cycles in humans?

entry.title: their highest share of the vote (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the Labour Party received their highest share of the vote to date in the 1951 UK general election but still lost to the Conservatives, who received fewer votes?

entry.title: Youth Symphony Orchestra of Ukraine (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Oksana Lyniv founded the Youth Symphony Orchestra of Ukraine in 2016 and conducted them in thirty concerts across ten music festivals in 2022?

entry.title: The Cutting Edge: The Magic of Movie Editing (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the 2004 documentary The Cutting Edge: The Magic of Movie Editing contains interviews from dozens of film editors, including women under-represented in the field?

entry.title: Chris Hill (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that despite getting an offer from his dream basketball school, Notre Dame, Chris Hill instead chose Michigan State?

entry.title: Kentucky Educational Television (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that country music singer Waylon Jennings earned his GED by watching tapes of a Kentucky Educational Television series on his tour bus?

entry.title: the healthcare campaigner who pioneered organ donor cards in the UK (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the healthcare campaigner who pioneered organ donor cards in the UK placed a personal advertisement in The Times looking for a "cadaver kidney" for her son?
